thread.title_full: Fantasy football: Can’t get worse for Broncos’ hyped RB — so gamble now | New York Post

author: Drew Loftis
title: Fantasy football: Can’t get worse for Broncos’ hyped RB — so gamble now
text:
There were some questions surrounding C.J. Anderson heading into this season, but not enough to scare off fantasy owners — hence him sneaking into the first round of drafts just before the season started.
Mostly he inspired confidence, based on how he finished 2014. Through injury or poor performance or both, Montee Ball and Ronnie Hillman couldn’t lock down the bellcow role. When it finally fell in Anderson’s lap, he took full advantage — he tallied 648 yards and eight touchdowns rushing, and another 131 yards and a score receiving over the final six games.
There was some worry Peyton Manning’s slump at the finish of last season would carry over into this season, allowing defenses to focus more on the running game. But that also meant Anderson likely was to get more chances, something likely to happen anyway in new coach Gary Kubiak’s offense.
The biggest worry was the offensive line, which underwent a massive overhaul. And the results thus far couldn’t be much worse.
Anderson has yet to find the end zone through three games. But it gets worse: He hasn’t even topped 30 yards rushing in a game. But it gets worse: His per-carry average is a disgusting 2.3. But it gets worse: His offensive line isn’t magically going to become more talented.
So what’s the good news? Talent alone doesn’t make an strong O-line. You need continuity, and that comes with time spent playing together. So there is reason to believe we are seeing the worst of Anderson.
Based on his phenomenal production at the end of last season, and the presumption the line will improve, the Madman is willing to buy low on Anderson, if the right deal can be found. Be before you do, realize there is a risk. There are no guarantees the line will get markedly better, but I am willing to gamble it will provided I don’t have to bet too much.
In the meantime, if you have a fantasy juggernaut and can afford to sit him, do so. But chances are his upside is better than what you have on the bench, in which case you play him. But steer clear in daily formats, where his price still is too high (DraftKings $5,900, FanDuel $6,900)
Big weeks Derek Carr Photo: AP Derek Carr QB, Raiders; at Bears (DraftKings $5,300/FanDuel $7,000)
The Bears have given up eight passing TDs this season — including seven in the first two games. Carr is enjoying WRs Amari Cooper and Michael Crabtree.
Karlos Williams RB, Bills; vs. Giants (DK $3,400/FD $6,300)
With LsSean McCoy out, Williams becomes a must-start in season-long formats and a strong, affordable daily option — though he will have high usage. And the matchup isn’t bad either.
Marvin Jones WR, Bengals; vs. Chiefs (DK $3,800/FD $5,500)
This isn’t a reflection of the Chiefs’ pass defense, which is better than its bottom-five ranking. But Kansas City will sell out on stopping A.J. Green, which should leave Jones open frequently.
Martellus Bennett TE, Bears; vs. Raiders (DK $4,500/FD $5,500)
This is a case in which the distrust of all things Bears is outweighed by the trust in the Raiders’ defensive apathy against tight ends. Oakland has allowed more than 100 yards per game to TEs and five total TDs in three games — a group that includes also-rans Crockett Gillmore and Gary Barnidge.
Small weaks Ryan Tannehill Photo: Getty Images Ryan Tannehill QB, Dolphins ; vs. Jets (DK $6,200/FD $7,700)
Put him on the bench indefinitely at this point, and certainly this week against the stout Jets defense. If CB Darrelle Revis plays, bench WR Jarvis Landry as well.
Jeremy Hill RB Bengals; vs. Chiefs (DK $6,500/FD $6,700)
Expecting a Hill rebound long-term, but plan for another disappointing outing first. Chiefs rank second in fantasy points allowed by RBs. but with team likely in pass mode, heavy use of Giovani Bernard will cut into Hill’s opportunities.
Keenan Allen WR, Chargers; vs. Browns (DK $7,000/FD $7,700)
Stellar Cleveland cover man Joe Haden had a rough go last week covering Amari Cooper. This just in: Keenan Allen is no Amari Cooper.
St. Louis D/ST, Rams; at Cardinals (DK $2,700/FD $4,400)
The sixth-highest scoring defense/special teams unit looks like a bargain in daily leagues, but employ judiciously. Arizona has showed they can score some points.

The Decision 
Post fantasy Madman Drew Loftis and Roto Files columnist Jarad Wilk debate whom you should start this week :
Andy Dalton vs. Cam Newton 
Drew : Dalton — Dalton can throw to A.J. Green, Marvin Jones, Tyler Efiert and Mohamed Sanu, and hand to Jeremy Hill and Giovani Bernard. Newton, who may be without RBs Jonathan Stewart and Mike Tolbert, could find himself handing to Fozzy Whittaker while throwing to Philly Brown. Sounds like a bad episode of “The Muppets.”
Jarad : Newton — Newton has played without receivers and running backs his entire career, yet still has gotten the job done. In six career games against the Buccaneers, Newton has thrown for 1,414 yards and 10 TDs (he also has rushed for 281 yards and six TDs). If history tells us anything, Newton will get it done with his arm and legs, while Dalton may be in for a letdown (in three games after throwing for 300 yards last year, he completed just 55.2 percent of his passes while throwing for one TD and one INT).
Last week : Drew 3 (Michael Crabtree — 36 receiving yards), Jarad 0 (Torrey Smith — 0 receiving yards)
Season series : Drew leads, 3-0
